Award.AwardTitle: Control Of Over-Actuated Nonlinear Systems With Application To High-Efficiency Internal Combustion Engines

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to establish a control design methodology for nonlinear systems possessing redundant control inputs, suitable for application to supervisory control of advanced combustion engines. The need for a comprehensive approach to the control and optimization of nonlinear over-actuated systems is warranted in a variety of engineering applications to fully exploit the potential benefits arising from redundant actuation. This is especially true for combustion engines, where simultaneous control of engine breathing and combustion can only be achieved by combining the effect of heterogeneous actuators. The proposed approach aims at overcoming fundamental limitations by exploiting a geometric characterization of system redundancy to determine the structure of the controller. The integration of two control strategies is pursued, one aiming at regulating the output, the other at shaping the transient response through online optimization. The overall integrated approach is novel and is expected to extend the state of the art in the theory and practice of control of complex nonlinear systems.

Central to the automotive industry is the need to improve fuel efficiency in light of the increasingly stringent government mandates and fuel price increases. However, significant benefits can only be achieved if advancements in engine design can be matched by improvements in controlling engine performance. The outcome of this research will lead to better fuel economy and emissions control and significantly shorten the development and integration of new engine technologies, a process that today is significantly slowed by the use of empirically based design and ad-hoc calibration procedures. Collaboration with industry will be pursued and fostered by the use of testing facilities for hardware verification. Integration of research and education will be achieved and enhanced through the involvement of undergraduate honor students, especially from under-represented groups, and collaboration with foreign academic institutions that leverage existing student exchange agreements.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the advancements in engine and powertrain technology, the automotive industry is seeking control and optimization methods that cater to dynamical systems characterized by a large number of degrees of freedom available for control. This is especially true for downsized boosted engines, where simultaneous control of engine breathing and combustion can only be achieved by coordinating and optimizing the effect of multiple heterogeneous actuators. 

This project led to the development of a comprehensive approach to the control and optimization of over-actuated systems based on the concept of Dynamic Control Allocation (DCA), with the goal of fully exploiting the benefits arising from redundant actuation.  The approach developed in this project hinged on a geometric characterization of system redundancy that lead to the synthesis of plug-in control strategies (that is, amenable to being integrated within existing control architectures) aiming at shaping both the transient and the steady-state response through online optimization. In particular, Model-Predictive (MP) optimization methods have been devised for on-line coordination of redundant inputs, with the goal of simultaneously optimizing performance criteria and enforcing input and state-dependent constraints. The theoretical framework of MP-DCA was developed for linear over-actuated systems, and extended to linear hybrid (switching and time-varying) systems.  

The project was completed successfully. In particular, this approach was demonstrated to replace the current processes in use, which rely on multi-objective optimization and requires significant amounts of calibration. Application to the coordination of a Diesel engine air path with Exhaust Gas Recirculation (EGR), Variable Geometry Turbine (VGT) and Variable Geometry Compressor (VGC) showed that the developed approach allows one to jointly achieve the tracking of the outputs and optimization of system performance, without performing trade-offs between such objectives. For this specific case study, significant improvements have been observed in comparison with a traditional Model-Predictive Control (MPC) approach, both in terms of achievable performance and reduced computational burden.

This award has graduated one Ph.D. students, two B.S. Honor Undergraduate students and supported a Post-Doc researcher. The project has strengthened collaborations with foreign institutions, namely the University of Trento (Italy), the University of Rome, "Tor Vergata" (Italy), LAARS-CNRS (France) and the Center for Automated Complex Systems (Italy). The material developed during this project contributed in strengthening the material taught in graduate courses offered in the Electrical and Computer Engineering program, namely ECE 6750 "Linear Systems Theory" and ECE 8754 "Nonlinear and Adaptive Control".

The outcome of the research was shared among the scientific community through four papers in journals with high impact factor,  five peer-reviewed papers in the top conferences in the field, numerous presentations and seminars, and was transferred to the automotive industry. Ford Motor Company is currently supporting further research efforts originated under this award, extending the theory developed to the coordination and optimization of hybrid electric vehicles and downsized boosted DISI engines.
